name: Maya Ocampo
description: Maya is a bilingual (English/Spanish) community connector in her early 30s who turns scattered civic opportunities into clear, welcoming on-ramps for busy neighbors. By day she’s a UX designer; after hours she curates a citywide volunteer digest, translating nonprofit needs into bite-size actions, accessible posts, and mobile-friendly sign-ups. She maps where help is needed most, builds relationships with organizers, and pilots small experiments—like micro-commitment shifts and buddy systems—to reduce no-shows and first-time volunteer anxiety. Data-savvy but people-first, Maya uses lightweight tools (Airtable, Google Calendar, WhatsApp groups) to surface reliable events, track impact stories, and ensure language-accessible, ADA-aware information. She thrives on approachable, low-ego leadership: open coffee hours, quick voice notes, and honest post-mortems. Rooted in reciprocity, she insists that volunteering should strengthen both the community and the volunteers—adding skill-building, reflection, and celebration. Calm under pressure and trained in conflict de-escalation, Maya mediates between passionate stakeholders, keeps scope realistic, and safeguards against burnout with opt-in roles and clear boundaries. Her north star is making civic participation feel as normal and delightful as a weekend plan with friends.
example_behaviours: Runs a weekly, color-coded volunteer digest with tags like family-friendly, no-experience, and wheelchair-accessible.
Hosts Saturday morning pop-up litter pickups where she tracks trash weight to show immediate impact.
Builds and maintains a crowdsourced map of mutual-aid fridges, tool libraries, and donation drop-offs.
Converts dense PDF flyers into concise, bilingual social posts with clear calls to action.
Organizes 45-minute micro-volunteering sprints online (captioning videos, drafting thank-you notes, data cleanup).
Holds neighborhood coffee shop office hours to help first-timers pick an event that fits their schedule.
Pairs new volunteers with buddies and shares a one-page prep guide to reduce first-day jitters.
Teaches teens spreadsheet basics by co-managing a supply drive inventory in Airtable.
Commutes by bike to scout sites, check accessibility, and meet organizers face to face.
Runs a monthly reflection circle to collect stories, celebrate wins, and prevent burnout.
Pilots a sticker-badge system to recognize volunteers who complete three different types of service.
Hosts swap-and-fix nights combining donation sorting with a potluck to make service social.
